expectedResults.title: Cross-Site Scripting in Name Parameter
expectedResults.reason: The expected XSS vulnerability in the name parameter (app.py lines 69-80) was completely missed by the penetration test. While the actual findings identified missing security headers including X-XSS-Protection and Content-Security-Policy, they did not identify the actual XSS vulnerability in the application code itself. The pentest focused on infrastructure-level security misconfigurations rather than testing application input validation and discovering the bypassable XSS filter. No attempt was made to test the name parameter with XSS payloads or demonstrate JavaScript execution.

actualResults.title: Server Version Information Disclosure in HTTP Headers
actualResults.assessment: Valid finding - This is a legitimate security misconfiguration. The application exposes outdated server version information (Werkzeug 1.0.1 and Python 2.7.18, both end-of-life) in HTTP headers, which aids attackers in reconnaissance and targeted exploitation. This is a new discovery not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Missing Security Headers
actualResults.assessment: Valid finding - This is a legitimate security misconfiguration. The application is missing critical security headers (X-Frame-Options, Content-Security-Policy, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Strict-Transport-Security) that would provide defense-in-depth protection against various attacks including XSS, clickjacking, and MITM attacks. This is a new discovery not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Information Disclosure via ETags in Static File Handler
actualResults.assessment: Valid finding - This is a legitimate information disclosure issue. The verbose ETag format exposes file metadata including timestamps, file sizes, and inode/hash information that could aid in reconnaissance and version fingerprinting. While low severity, this is a valid security concern and a new discovery not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Overly Permissive Cache-Control Headers on Static Files
actualResults.assessment: Valid finding - This is a legitimate security misconfiguration. The 'public' directive with 12-hour max-age allows sensitive files to be cached in shared proxies and CDNs, potentially leading to information disclosure and stale content issues. While low severity, this is a valid security concern and a new discovery not in the expected findings.
